question_text: Explain the physical origin of preferential concentration in turbulent flows for particles with Kolmogorov Stokes number (Stη) near unity, including the role of vortex centrifuging and its impact on particle spatial distribution.
standard_answer: Preferential concentration arises when Stη ≈ 1, where particles exhibit inertia-driven clustering in regions of low vorticity. This phenomenon stems from the balance between particle response time (τp) and Kolmogorov time scale (τη). In turbulent eddies, centrifugal forces expel particles from high-vorticity cores due to their finite inertia, preventing them from following intense rotational motions. Particles accumulate in strain-dominated regions (e.g., braids between vortices) where fluid acceleration is lower. The mechanism involves: (1) Vortex cores generating centripetal acceleration that particles resist, leading to outward drift; (2) Strain regions with compressive motion concentrating particles; (3) Clustering scales on the order of the Kolmogorov length (η), as particles segregate based on local flow topology. This bias enhances collision frequencies and alters mixing, critical in combustion sprays or pollutant dispersion, where localized concentrations affect reaction rates or deposition.

original_text.1: When Stη~1, particles tend to be closely grouped in some regions and be completely absent in other regions, known as 'preferential concentration'. In particular, particles tend to accumulate in thin-banded regions with concentration thicknesses on the order of the Kolmogorov length scale (η).
